questions.text: A 23-year-old woman suffers from emotional lability, fatigue, bloating, headache, sleeplessness, and breast tenderness about 10 days before her menses. These symptoms are relieved once she starts menstruating. All of the following are recommended in the management of this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of Premenstrual syndrome (PMS). All the above-mentioned measures are recommended in the management of PMS except caffeine.

Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS) is a symptom complex associated with ovulatory cycles. It starts 7 to 14 days prior to menstruation and spontaneously resolves after menses. It occurs in the luteal phase of the cycle. When this symptom complex causes significant impairment, a diagnosis of premenstrual dysphoric disorder(PMDD) is made according to DSM-5.

Symptoms of PMS include:

  • Pain:- Headache, breast pain, abdominal cramps, muscle stiffness, backache and generalized body ache.
  • Water retention:- Breast volume increase, bloating and weight gain.
  • Behavioural changes:- Low performance, difficulty in concentration, irritability, depression, forgetfulness, low judgement, anxiety, loneliness, feeling like crying, hostility, increased appetite and cravings and sleeplessness.
  • Autonomic changes:- Dizziness, faintness, nausea, vomiting and hot flushes.

Premenstrual syndrome can be managed by dietary changes and lifestyle modifications like yoga, exercises and relaxation activities. Pharmacological therapy includes the usage of primrose oil, vitamin B1, vitamin B6, vitamin E, calcium and magnesium supplements. Foods and beverages rich in sugar and caffeine can aggravate premenstrual symptoms in some women and are generally avoided. 

Symptoms can be alleviated by the use of prostaglandin inhibitors (ibuprofen and naproxen ), Selective Serotonin Reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) like fluoxetine, GABA antagonists and anxiolytics such as alprazolam. Danazol, bromocriptine and GnRH analogues can be used to reduce breast pain. OCPs with spironolactone and Mirena IUCD can also be used.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the procedure shown below?

POG- Period of gestation

choices.text: Can be used in fetus with gestational age less than 34 weeks
Can be used in cases of fetal coagulopathy
Can be used for both vertex and face presentations
Flexion point is 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
The above image shows a vacuum-assisted delivery. The flexion point is about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. 

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp. During vacuum-assisted delivery, the suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput, called the flexion point. A flexion point is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanelle.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery include:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks POG)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

Below is the image of vacuum extractor 

Traction should be abandoned if:

  • There is no decent of the presenting part with each pull
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed more than 30 minutes. 

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Vacuum delivery has reduced maternal pelvic floor injury, and it is the instrument of the choice in assisted delivery.

Vacuum-assisted vaginal deliveries may fail due to selection of incorrect cup size or accidental inclusion of maternal soft tissues within the cup or incorrect placement of the cup which results in malpresentation of the fetal head.

While in forceps deliveries, it is unlikely to detach from the fetal head and allows the fetal head for rotation. It can be used in premature fetuses and cause relatively less bleeding from the scalp. This makes forceps have a higher success rate as compared to vacuum-assisted delivery. 

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ovarian follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding.

 Ovarian follicular cysts are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage, or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, ulcer, or cervical carcinoma.
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text:
Which of the following parameters are included in the modified Biophysical profile score?
  1. Oxytocin challenge test
  2. Contraction stress test
  3. Amniotic fluid index
  4. Vibroacoustic nonstress test
  5. Amniotic fluid volume
questions.solution:
Vibroacoustic nonstress test/Nonstress test (NST) and Amniotic fluid index (AFI) (options 3 and 4) are included in the modified biophysical score.

Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score provides a means of accessing fetal health. Involves the measurement of the following: (Mnemonic: BATMaN)

  • B-Breathing 
  • A-Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
  • T-Tone of fetus
  • M-Movements of fetus
  • N-Non Stress Test (NST)

Normal score: >=8 (with normal AFV). The maximum score is 10.

Abnormal scores:

  • 8/10 with decreased AFV: suspicion of chronic fetal asphyxia
  • 6/10: Possible fetal asphyxia
  • 4/10: Probable fetal asphyxia
  • 0-2/10: Almost certain fetal asphyxia

Maternal sedatives and narcotics can significantly lower the score.

The biophysical profile was modified to includes two parameters- the biweekly vibroacoustic nonstress test or Nonstress test and the AFI. 

The nonstress test describes fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements, using a Doppler to detect fetal heart rate acceleration. Fetal movements are recorded as perceived by the mother. Acoustic stimula­tion nonstress test is one in which a loud external sound is used to startle the fetus and provoke heart rate accelerations.

  • Normal modified BPP: Reactive nonstress test with AFI>5cm
  • Abnormal modified BPP: nonreactive nonstress test or AFI <5 cm 

Oxytocin challenge test (Contraction stress test): The fetal heart rate and uterine contrac­tions are recorded simultaneously with an external monitor. If at least three spontaneous contractions of 40 seconds or longer are present in 10 minutes, uterine stimulation is not required. If required, it can be done with iv oxytocin or nipple stimulation.

A positive test(abnormal) is uniform repetitive late fetal heart rate decelerations, which could indicate uteroplacental insufficiency. A negative test would show no late or significant variable decelerations.

The nonstress test is a test of fetal condition, while the contraction stress test is a test of uteroplacental function.

Contraindications of contraction stress testing:

  • Compromised fetus
  • Previous history of cesarean section
  • Complications likely to produce preterm labor
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Multiple pregnancies

questions.text: In a woman diagnosed with infertility, which of the following antihormonal substance can be used to induce ovulation?
questions.solution:
Clomiphene citrate is an antihormonal substance used to induce ovulation in a patient diagnosed with infertility. Ovulation can be induced by giving clomiphene citrate 50 mg daily, starting from day 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle for 5 days.

Related Pearl: Management of female infertility for different causes are as follows

Etiology Investigations Management  
Tubal cause
  • Hysterosalpingography or sonosalpingography
  • Falloscopy
  • Salpingography
  • Laparoscopic chromotubation
  • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis
  • Tuboplasty
  • Hysteroscopic cannulation and balloonplasty
  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT 
Ovulation related           
  • Ovulation monitoring by ultrasound (BBT, BBI) And  Endometrial Biopsy for tuberculosis done    
  • If the above steps are abnormal, do a hormonal study
  • FSH, LH, Prolactin
  • E2, P level
  • Thyroid and diabetes
  • Clomiphene and letrozole
  • If it fails, give FSH, LH, GnRH
  • Check for a response; if there is no response do IVF Donor egg.
  • If all the above measures fail, the final option is to adopt  
Other causes   Ultrasound, MRI, SSG, hysteroscopy   Treat the cause

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with complaints of inability to conceive despite regular intercourse for the past 2 years.  Physical examination and semen analysis are normal. Hysterosalpingography reveals the following picture. The anomaly in the image below falls under which category of the American Fertility Society classification of Mullerian duct anomalies?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hysterosalpingogram of a unicornuate uterus, which falls under Class II of Mullerian duct anomalies

In the unicornuate uterus, the formation of the uterus and fallopian tube occurs entirely from one Mullerian duct due to the developmental arrest of other Mullerian ducts. On Hysterosalpingography, the endometrial cavity usually appears fusiform shape tapering at the apex and draining into a single fallopian tube. The uterus generally appears shifted off the midline.

The AFS (American Fertility Society) classification of Mullerian duct anomalies is as follows:

  • Class I—Mullerian agenesis or hypoplasia.
  • Class II—Unicornuate uterus, with absent or defective development of one Mullerian duct.
  • Class III—Uterus didelphys
  • Class IV—Bicornuate uterus 
  • Class V—Septate uterus
  • Class VI—Arcuate uterus

Infertility is defined as lack of conception despite 12 months of regular unprotected intercourse in women aged < 35 years old and despite 6 months of regular unprotected intercourse in women aged > 35 years old.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:

choices.text: Delivery of occipitotransverse position in platypelloid pelvis
Delivery of after coming head in breech delivery
Outlet forceps used to provide traction force

questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is an outlet forceps used to provide traction force.

 Wrigley's forceps are used exclusively in outlet forceps operations for the extraction of the head. It is used to provide traction force. The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. Outlet forceps are used when:

  • The fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia
  • The fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, at or on the perineum
  • The sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°)

Other options:

Option A: Kielland forceps are used in correcting asynctilism.

Option B: Barton forceps are used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.

Option C: Piper forceps have a distinct perineal curve and allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: A young woman, who was diagnosed with threatened abortion was referred to you from the peripheral hospital for an ultrasonography. Examination of this patient would reveal:

choices.text: Closed cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG
Closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG
Dilated cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG
Dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG

questions.solution:
Examination of a patient diagnosed with threatened abortion would reveal closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows well-formed gestation ring indicating healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Abortion is the expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A: In missed abortion, the fetus is dead and is retained inside the uterus for a variable period. Here closed cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Option C: In incomplete abortion, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity. Here dilated cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Option D: In inevitable abortion, the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible. Here dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised of brachytherapy. Choose the false statement regarding this treatment modality.

choices.text: Intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to squared distance
Tandems are placed in the vagina
Point B is 2 cm above and 5 cm lateral  to the external os
Point A receives a dose of 7000 cGy

questions.solution:
The false statement about this treatment modality is that the tandems are placed in the vagina. The tandems are placed in the uterine cavity whereas the ovoids and colpostats are placed in the vaginal vault.

Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. It can be either a low-dose or high-dose rate system. High-dose brachytherapy is safe and effective.

Dosage is calculated with respect to the amount of radiation received at two arbitrary points A and B (image below).

  Point A Point B
Location 2cm above and 2cm lateral to the external os 2cm above and 5cm lateral to the external os
Structure present crossing of the ureter and uterine artery Obturator lymph node
Dose of radiation 7000-8000 cGy 6000 cGy (2000 cGy by brachytherapy + 4000 cGy by external beam radiotherapy)

 

Different techniques of brachytherapy:

 Techniques Device  No. of application Duration
Stockholm 

Intrauterine tandem

One vaginal plaque

 Three 24 hours each weekly
Paris

Intrauterine tandem

Three vaginal ovoids

 One 120 hours
Manchester

Intrauterine tandem

Two vaginal ovoids

 TWo 72 hours each weekly

Radiation dose in surrounding normal tissue is less due to inverse square law (Inverse square law - the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to squared distance from the source of radiation). This method is unsuitable for large tumours and has potential risks of radiation exposure to medical staff.

Note: After loading technique by remote control is the recent development of brachytherapy. It protects the staff from radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old overweight female presents with complaints of infertility despite regular unprotected intercourse with her husband for the past 3 years. Her USG findings are shown in the image below. The medical treatments advised by her previous doctors haven't given any results, so she prefers surgical management. Identify the incorrect option regarding the surgical management of her condition.

choices.text: Not more than two cysts are to be drilled in each ovary laparoscopically
Surgery is indicated if overstimulation occurs
Chromotubation and tubal testing can be done at the same time
Other causes of infertility like endometriosis can be assessed

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound showing multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern suggest polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). Not more than four ovarian cysts are punctured/drilled in each ovary in polycystic ovary syndrome.

PCOS is a common endocrine disorder in a reproductive-age woman characterized by oligomenorrhoea, non-ovulation (infertility), obesity, and hirsutism. Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (alopecia, acne, hirsutism)
  • Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhoea/non-ovulation)
  • Polycystic ovaries

Surgery is indicated when medical treatment fails, overstimulation happens, infertile individuals, and loss of pregnancies in the past (Option B) 

Surgery comprises laparoscopic drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It is done using a laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrinal balance and improves fertility for a year or so.

The advantages of surgery are as follows: 

  • Chromotubation and tubal testing can be done at the same time (Option C) 
  • One can search for additional infertility causes, such as endometriosis (Option D) 
  • There is no need for extensive or continuous side effect monitoring
  • Economical in contrast to IVF
  • Decreases the synthesis of LH and androgen
  • After surgery, medication is used to induce single ovulation to prevent hyperstimulation and multiple pregnancies 
  • 60%–70% of women experience pregnancy, and 80–90% ovulate

The disadvantages of surgery are as follows:

  • It involves giving anaesthesia and performing an invasive procedure like laparoscopy
  • Adhesions may form postoperatively. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may again reduce the fertility rate. 
  • If cautery is used, premature ovarian failure due to destruction of ovarian tissue may be seen

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A primigravida woman underwent a normal vaginal delivery at her home following which she presented with a perineal tear as shown below. Identify the grade of perineal tear:
questions.solution:
The image showing a tear in the vaginal mucosa, perineal muscles, and more than 50% of the external anal sphincter is suggestive of a grade 3b perineal tear.

Perineal tears are common in primigravida women undergoing vaginal delivery.

The first-degree tears do not require repairs but suturing of laceration prevents the vaginal orifice from becoming patulous. Second-degree tears must be immediately sutured after the delivery of the placenta to prevent the weakening of the pelvic floor and genital prolapse. 

Third and fourth-degree tears must be efficiently repaired to prevent flatus and faecal incontinence. Such tears are common in median episiotomies, incorrect usage of forceps in a persistent occipitoposterior positioned fetus, delivery of aftercoming of breech, precipitate labour and delivery of macrosomic babies.

The best time for repair of a complete perineal tear is within 24 hours of the injury. If not done within 24hrs, it is preferably done 3-6 months after delivery. If the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms and making the surgery difficult. 

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility. The cervical mucus shows the following appearance on microscopy. During which phase of the menstrual cycle is the given finding seen?

choices.text: Estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
The image shows a characteristic ferning pattern of cervical mucus seen during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle. 

The characteristics of cervical mucous changes under the influence of estrogen and progesterone. During the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle, the cervical mucus is thin and stretchy due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus which shows the characteristic pattern seen above. This pattern disappears once ovulation has taken place due to the activity of progesterone. If previously present, its disappearance is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.  

At the time of ovulation, the mucus becomes thin, watery, and clear that can be stretched up to 10cm. This is called spinnbarkeit or thread test and is presumptive of ovulation. During the progesterone phase, the mucus becomes thick and tenacious, impermeable to the sperms.

Other signs of ovulation are

  • An increase in basal body temperature(BBT) after ovulation due to the thermogenic action of the hormone progesterone. 
  • Urinary LH peak (increase in LH) is usually seen 1 day prior to ovulation.
  • The growth of ovarian follicles is 20 mm or more in size on USG at the time of ovulation.

The menstrual cycle consists of three phases: the menstrual phase, the proliferative phase, and the secretory, or progestational, phase

The menstrual phase is characterized by the discharge of blood and endometrial debris from the vagina due to the withdrawal of progesterone and the degeneration of the corpus luteum (CL).

The proliferative phase is estrogen-dominant and lasts from the end of menstruation to ovulation. It results in the proliferation of endometrial glands and thickened endometrium.

The secretory or progestational phase is progesterone dominant which converts the thickened, estrogen-primed endometrium to a richly vascularized, glycogen-filled tissue for early nourishment of a developing embryo. If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and a new follicular phase and menstrual phase begin again.

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text:
You are a medical officer on camp duty seeing patients who have come for the removal of contraceptive devices. You notice the following contraceptive devices being used. Which of the following is incorrect about these devices?

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease - PID

choices.text: Can be used as an emergency contraceptive
Can be used in patients with mennorrhagia

questions.solution:
The image shows types of Copper T. The statement that it 'can be used in patients with menorrhagia' is incorrect about the copper T. Copper T's are contraindicated in patients with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and anemia as it can worsen the condition. 

Copper T is a type of intrauterine contraception device (IUCD). They provide long-term, reversible method of contraception.

Types:

  • Medicated IUCD's such as progestasert, levonova, and mirena which release hormones for contraception.
  • Unmedicated IUCD's such as the copper T, in order to induce contraception. 

The copper T functions by causing an inflammatory response within the uterus which leads to spermicide. The same response also makes it difficult for blastocyst implantation. 

IUCDs can be placed in women who have a low risk of sexually transmitted diseases, are multiparous, monogamous, and want long-term contraception without permanent sterilization. These have the advantage of not having to take a daily oral contraceptive pill. 

The copper T can also be used as emergency contraception (Option A) and left inside the uterus long term for contraception. 

It is contraindicated in the following situations: 

  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Fibroid uterus (Option C) as there will be structural issues
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (Option D) or lower genital tract infections
  • Menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea
  • Anemia
  • Uncontrolled diabetes due to increased risk of infection
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy 
  • Scarred uterus
  • Abnormally shaped uterus

In addition, hormonal IUCDs should not be given in women with history of breast cancer. 

The following image shows the Nova T. It has silver in addition to the copper wire which makes its lifespan 5 years. 

The copper T 380A is also known as Paraguard. It has a lifespan of 10 years. It has 380 mm2 surface area spread out across the stem and the sleeves. 

The multiload 375 has 375 mm2 of copper wire wrapped around the stem. It has to be replaced every 5 years. It does not have an introducer or plunger. 

The copper T 200 has 215mm2 of copper around the stem. It has a polyethylene frame with monofilaments attached to the end of the stem. The threads are used for removal. Barium sulfate is added to the stem to increase radioopacity when performing xrays. It has a lifespan of 3 years. 

The following images represent the copper T 380A, multiload 375, and copper T 200. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Bleeding during normal menstruation occurs due to rupture of ____
questions.solution:
Rupture of the spiral arteries causes bleeding during normal menstruation. This is a branch of the uterine artery. 

The blood supply of the uterus is as follows:

Uterine artery→Arcuate artery→Radial artery→Basal artery→Spiral artery

questions.text: Menopause is defined as cessation of menses for a period of _____.
questions.solution: Menopause is defined as cessation of ovarian function for 12 months resulting in permanent amenorrhoea. It is a retrospective diagnosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida developed fever and pruritic vesicular rashes one day after a full-term normal vaginal delivery. A diagnosis of varicella infection was made. How should the neonate be managed?

choices.text: Acyclovir therapy should be started immediately

questions.solution:
Passive immunization with Varicella-Zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is administered to neonates whose mothers develop a varicella-zoster rash from five days before delivery up to two days after delivery.

If the fetus or neonate is exposed to active varicella infection just before or during delivery, they may develop a disseminated visceral and central nervous system disease, which can be fatal. Neonte is not at risk of severe neonatal chicken pox, if mother contracts infection before and after this period (i.e 5 days before and 2 days after delivery), in that case passive immunisation is not required.

VZIG may not prevent infection, but reduces the severity of neonatal infection. Monitoring of the neonate should be prolonged to 28 days, as VZIG may prolong the incubation period.

If signs of neonatal infection develop despite VZIG, the neonate should be treated with acyclovir. 

Primary varicella infection presents with flu-like symptoms, followed by a pruritic vesicular rash. The fetus may develop congenital varicella syndrome if infection occurs in the first half of pregnancy, the highest risk is between 13 and 20 weeks. Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

Pregnant women who are exposed to varicella and are susceptible should be given VZIG. Infected women usually require only supportive care, but those who require intravenous (IV) fluids and or develop pneumonia should be hospitalized. Intravenous acyclovir therapy is given to women requiring hospitalization.

questions.text: According to the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation of labour progress begins at a cervical dilatation of -
questions.solution:
According to the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation of labour progress begins at a cervical dilatation of 5cm. 

WHO Labour Care Guidelines:

  • Time axis - examination findings are plotted every one hour 
  • Alert column- has values which if reached indicates the need for urgent medical intervention
  • Active first stage - findings are plotted every hour upto 12 hours. If the first stage continues, a new sheet is used.
  • Second stage - plotted every hour upto 3 hours

1) Section 1: Preliminary information

Name, parity, labour onset, active labour diagnosis (date), ruptured membranes (date&time), risk factors

2) Section 2: Supportive care

  • Companionship  
  • Pain relief 
  • Oral fluid 
  • Posture 

3) Section 3: Baby

  • Baseline FHR
  • FHR deceleration
  • Amniotic fluid
  • Fetal position
  • Caput
  • Moulding

4) Section 4: Vitals 

Pulse, SBP, DBP, temperature, and urine for proteins are recorded every 4 hours

5) Section 5: Labour progress

  • Count the number of uterine contractions over a 10-minute period. 
  • Assess the duration of contractions
  • Cervical dilatation: starts at 5 cm and is plotted as X; it is assessed every hour. For example - if the cervical dilatation remains at 5cm for ≥ 6hrs, it indicates the need for urgent intervention. Similarly, the cut-offs for - 6cm is ≥ 5hrs; 7cm is ≥ 3hrs; 8cm is ≥ 2.5hrs; 9cm is ≥ 2 hrs
  • Descent - plotted as O

6) Section 6: Medication

  • Oxytocin 
  • Medicine 
  • IV fluids

7) Section 7: Shared decision making

  • Assessment
  • Plan

*Fetal position, vitals of the mother and cervical dilatation can be assessed at 4 hourly if the labour is progressing adequately

*If birth is not completed by 3 hours from the start of the active second stage in nulliparous and 2 hours in multiparous women, intervention is needed
